Award.AwardTitle: Designing Intermolecular Interactions for High-Performance Small-Molecule Bulk Heterojunctions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: In this project, optoelectronic properties of small-molecule donor-acceptor materials are systematically explored, with the ultimate goal of developing soluble donor-and-acceptor molecules for efficient small-molecule bulk heterojunction solar cells and novel sensitizers (acceptors) for photorefractive devices with improved properties. The project aims to fulfill the following three objectives: to establish dependence of charge photogeneration, transport, and recombination on the relative energies of the donor-and-acceptor molecules and molecular packing (macroscopic level); to quantify contributions of the donor-and-acceptor domains and donor-acceptor interfacial areas to charge photogeneration, transport, and recombination depending on the donor-and-acceptor molecules and their packing (microscopic level); and to determine molecular photophysics, three-dimensional alignment and domain formation tendencies, of guest acceptor molecules in crystalline donor hosts depending on the molecular structures of the donor-and-acceptor molecules and disorder (single-molecule level). Effects of sample fabrication and processing are also studied. In order to fulfill these objectives, measurements of time-resolved photocurrent (including scanning photocurrent microscopy) and time-resolved fluorescence (including near-field scanning optical microscopy and single-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy) combined with numerical modeling are carried out.

Non-technical Description: One of the most important aspects of the project is its potential impact on solar and photorefractive three-dimensional display technology, as well as on other optoelectronic applications based on solution-processable organic films. The project integrates fundamental physics and chemistry with materials design and device technologies and thus provides interdisciplinary educational resources and infrastructure for postdoctoral researchers and graduate and undergraduate students contributing to research. The PI makes active efforts to involve undergraduates, including female and minority students, in the project. Based on research results, the research team develops educational materials, demonstrations, and web tutorials that are introduced into graduate and upper-level undergraduate physics and engineering courses to deepen students' understanding of the material as well as incorporated into events for college freshmen and high-school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we systematically explored optoelectronic properties of small-molecule donor-acceptor (D/A) materials (Fig. 1) important for applications in organic solar cells. We used carefully selected combinations of solution-processable high-mobility functionalized acene and thiophene derivatives as donors and acceptors and crafted our experiments to address issues pertaining to solar cell performance: charge carrier photogeneration, transport, and collection.

The project aimed to fulfill the following three objectives (Fig. 2): to establish dependence of charge photogeneration, transport, and recombination on the relative HOMO and LUMO energies of the donor and acceptor molecules and molecular packing (macroscopic level, Objective 1, Fig. 3); to quantify contributions of the donor and acceptor domains and D/A interfacial areas to charge photogeneration, transport, and recombination depending on the molecules and their packing (microscopic level, Objective 2), and to determine molecular photophysics and alignment of guest molecules in various hosts depending on the molecular structures and the host (single-molecule level, Objective 3). In order to fulfill these objectives, measurements of time-resolved photocurrent and time-resolved fluorescence (including single-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy) combined with numerical modeling were carried out.

Intellectual Merit

We established that charge carrier photogeneration in materials under study proceeds via different channels: ultrafast carrier separation, ns time-scale Frenkel exciton dissociation, and charge transfer (CT) exciton dissociation. Through numerical modeling of transient photocurrents, we quantified the distribution of photoexcitation among these channels depending upon film morphology, crystallinity, and properties of acceptors (Fig. 4). In particular, it was found that efficiency of ultrafast charge carrier separation strongly correlates with donor crystallinity (Fig. 4). Emissive CT formation was observed in several D/A blends, and the propensity of the CT state for dissociation depended upon the D/A separation at the D/A interfaces controlled by the side groups R on the acceptor molecule. Emission from CT states was utilized in mapping out network of D/A interfaces via PL imaging of films at the microscopic level. Studies of performance of solar cells containing molecules under study showed that morphologies that support emissive CT state formation are detrimental for power conversion efficiencies and must be avoided. Several functionalized organic semiconductor molecules were imaged on the single molecule level in polymeric and small-molecule crystalline hosts to reveal effects of nanoenvironment on the molecular photophysics and molecular packing constraints imposed by the host (Fig. 5). Properties of the molecules under study as fluorophores for single molecule fluorescence spectroscopy (SMFS) were quantified. High fluorescence quantum yields, coupled with high photostability, were observed in several derivatives. Improved photostability of fluorophores, and orientational constraints imposed on the fluorophore by the host, were observed in a crystalline host (Fig.3). These studies lay foundations for nanoscale level studies of bulk heterojunction formation using SMFS.

Broader impact.

The PI has made active efforts to involve undergraduates, as well as female and minority students, in research. The PI’s group was actively involved in educational demonstrations for undergraduate and high-school students for several physics and engineering courses and at various events. Using the major equipment part of the grant, we developed a low-temperature microscopy capability, which is now available to researchers at OSU and beyond as a shared facility.
